findings.title: No restrictions on minting to invalid recipients
findings.description: Certain transfer restrictions imposed in the LUSD ERC20 token are not properly handled during the minting.

findings.title: ERC20 transfer restriction can disturb 3rd-party interactions
findings.description: Certain transfer restrictions imposed in the Liquity ERC20 tokens can produce unexpected results in 3rd- party components interacting with the system.

findings.title: False positive: removed after discussion with Liquity team
Insufficient enforcement of immutability of system logic variables through the Solidity compiler
findings.description: The system logic of the Liquity Protocol is supposed to be immutable after deployment, but certain state variables are mutable and can be assigned a value after construction.

findings.title: Unclear if the gas pool account is controlled by someone
findings.description: The special gas pool account is used to mint LUSD tokens and pay for the gas operations performed by users, but it is unclear if someone owns its private key.

findings.title: Reentrancy could lead to incorrect order of emitted events
findings.description: The order of operations in the `_moveTokensAndETHfromAdjustment` function may allow an attacker to cause events to be emitted out of order.

findings.title: Missing address validation when configuring contracts
findings.description: The setAddresses functions in several contracts do not validate addresses before setting them, which can lead to incorrect addresses being set and potentially requiring redeployment of the entire system.

findings.title: Permit opens the door for griefing contracts that interact with the Liquity Protocol
findings.description: The `permit` function can be front-run to break the workflow from third-party smart contracts.

findings.title: Closing troves requires owners to hold the full amount of LUSD minted
findings.description: Users should hold the complete amount of LUSD minted before closing their trove, otherwise, the trove closing operation will fail.

findings.title: Failed lockup error is never thrown
findings.description: The locking contract function fails to signal an error in the return value, causing some error code to be unreachable.

findings.title: Duplicated functions pose future risk of diverging
findings.description: The `TroveManager` and `BorrowerOperations` contracts both contain a function to calculate the current TCR, although they currently are identical in terms of outcome, they differ in their implementation. This could pose future problems in case one is updated while the other one is not.

findings.title: Total system collateral and debt calculations are repeated multiple times
findings.description: The functions getEntireSystemColl() and getEntireSystemDebt() have duplicate implementations across TroveManager.sol and BorrowerOperations.sol, risking divergence and decreasing readability.

findings.title: Troves can be improperly removed under certain circumstances which results in unexpected reverts
findings.description: In certain circumstances, troves are not properly inserted in the sorted list and therefore, cannot be removed, causing unexpected revert and potential loss of funds.

findings.title: Initial redeem can unexpectedly revert if no redeemable troves
findings.description: The initial redemption in the system can cause an assertion to unexpectedly fail if there are no troves with ICR >= MCR.

findings.title: Redeem without redemptions might still return success
findings.description: redeem when there are no redeemable troves does not cause the transaction to revert.
